text: Life at Harvard is captured through multimedia every day—below we provide a small, curated selection of video, audio, and photography.
Songwriting collaboration treats war’s invisible wounds

A recent pilot study used songwriting to treat PTSD, depression and other “invisible wounds of war” among veterans and active duty military, which showed significant drops in self-reported PTSD and depression symptoms by participants.
Harvard Japanese art professor curates MET exhibit
Harvard’s Melissa McCormick takes “The Tale of the Genji,” one of the world’s first novels, from classroom to gallery.
Take a look at life and learning at Harvard, on campus and around the world.
What Works: Designing an Inclusive Workplace
Gender equality is a moral and a business imperative. Presenting research-based solutions, Iris Bohnet hands us the tools we need to move the needle in classrooms and boardrooms.
How Do you Combat Violent Extremism?
In this discussion on combating violent extremism, guest Farah Pandith has counter-intuitive views on how we do that.

Harvard faculty consider the Oxford Dictionaries' ‘word of the year’
Harvard faculty reflect on 2019's word of the year: “climate emergency."
Analysts discuss the 20-year rule of Vladimir Putin
Analysts look back at the unexpected rule of Russian President Vladimir Putin, now 20 years in power.
Harvard analysts probe what impeachment means, where it leads

To gain a better understanding of the issues in play following the House impeachment of President Donald Trump, the Gazette asked Harvard faculty and affiliates in history, law, politics, government, psychology, and media to offer their thoughts.
Over nearly 80 years, Harvard study has been showing how to live a healthy and happy life
For nearly 80 years, the Harvard Study of Adult Development has been producing data and lessons on how to live longer, happier, and healthier lives.

Harvard faculty and staff members share what they're reading this summer.
